title: Senator Kaine's Vote to End the Government Shutdown
summary: The government shutdown was a time when the government stopped working because leaders couldn't agree on a plan. Senator Tim Kaine from Virginia was one of eight Democrats who voted to end the shutdown. He explained that he wanted to change the situation and help people who were affected. This vote caused a split among Senate Democrats, with some agreeing and others disagreeing. Kaine talked to Geoff Bennett on PBS NewsHour to share his reasons. Ending the shutdown meant that government services could start again, which is important for many Americans.

background_read: A government shutdown happens when Congress cannot agree on a budget, leading to many services like national parks and benefits stopping. Senators are elected officials who represent states and vote on laws. Political parties like Democrats and Republicans often have different ideas, which can cause disagreements. In this case, the shutdown affected many people, and ending it was important to restart services.
